newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa's IDC cuts rates to boost manufacturing.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa's IDC cuts rates to boost manufacturing.

text.p: The state-owned Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) said on Wednesday it had reduced its interest rates in a bid to assist South Africa's medium-sized manufacturing sector.
It said that in terms of loan financing, its variable interest rates had been reduced to two percent and 2.5 percent below the prime overdraft rate -- currently 20.25 percent.
The variable rates on offer had now been set at 18.25 a year for loans below 25 million rand and 17.75 percent a year above 25 million rand, compared with 19.3 percent a year previously.
The IDC's fixed interest rate was set at 16.5 percent and was available to enterprises with total assets of under 60 million rand.

In addition, low interest rates on the IDC's special financing schemes, would now run for the full term of the loan with a maximum of six years as opposed to three years before. The special interest rates would be three percentage points below either the variable or fixed interest rates.
Special financing schemes are aimed at the promotion of job creation, exports and improved international competitiveness.
"This means that qualifying industrialists could obtain low interest rates in the range between 13.5 percent per annum and 15.25 percent per annum for six years," it said in a statement.
In an effort to support job creation, the qualifying criteria for its Jobs Scheme had been adjusted to take inflation into account.

"Industrialists creating new jobs at a total investment of less than 100,000 rand per job will now qualify for the low interest rate (of between 13.5 and 15.25 percent) compared with 50,000 rand per job before."
"The IDC believes that its new rates will stimulate industrial development, especially amongst medium sized manufacturing," it added.
